questions.question_text: Where can you find information about all supported operating systems for the Falcon sensor?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Documentation > Sensor Deployment and Maintenance > Mac, Windows, Linux

All listed OSs provide a supported OS table.

questions.question_text: What sensor update policy will a sensor receive if it does not have a host group assignment?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Documentation: Endpoint Security > Configuration > Detection and Prevention Policies > Title: Policy Precedence > para 4

If a host is not a part of any groups, or the groups it belongs to has no policies assigned, it is automatically assigned to the default policy.

questions.question_text: How would an installation token be configured if the Falcon Sensor was installed on a Red Hat Enterprise Linux host?

choices.A: You will be prompted to enter the installation token during the install if it is required

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
When installing the Sensor on a Red Hat (RHEL) host, you need to provide the Customer ID (CID) and Provisioning Token to properly install and configure the sensor. The command in option D correctly uses falconctl to configure the Falcon Sensor with both the --cid and --provisioning-token parameters, which is the standard way to provide these values during installation.

Selected Answer: B
B, the doc is clear.

Selected Answer: B
B. sudo yum install --cid= --provisioning-token=ABCD1234

choices.A: You cannot. You must list a specific file in an exclusion rule

questions.question_text: What is the best way to write an ML exclusion for any executable file at "C:\Program Files\Software\"?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is the best and most specific way to create an exclusion for any .exe file in the given directory.

choices.C: Create a Custom IOC and set it to "Allow" for "C:\Users\Bob\DevCode\felix.dll"
choices.A: Create a sensor visibility exclusion for "C:\Users\Bob\DevCode\felix.dll"
choices.D: Manually turn off the built-in IOA through prevention policies

questions.question_text: Your development team is working on a new enterprise application, but Falcon starts creating alerts during testing. The alert points to, "C:\Users\Bob\DevCode\felix.dll". In the detection, you see that it's triggering only on a specific Falcon IOA. What would be the best course of action for this situation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. Create an IOA exclusion for "C:\Users\Bob\DevCode\felix.dll"

In this situation, the alert is triggered by a specific Falcon Indicator of Attack (IOA), so the best course of action would be to create an IOA exclusion for the specific file path to prevent Falcon from flagging it during testing. This allows the development process to continue without compromising overall security, as the exclusion is targeted and specific to the identified IOA.

Selected Answer: B
Answer is B because the detection was for an IOA.

If you allow the hash of the DLL via a Custom IOC it will only affect Machine Learning based detections and not IOAs, which means it cannot be C
